Trait_description: Agriculture (horticulture) present (i.e., food plants cultivated)
Agriculture provides the major part of subsistence (about 75% or more)
Agricultural plots under relatively permanent cultivation except for periods of fallow (if they occur)
Improved techniques of planting (e.g., mounds, planting in rows, breaking of clods, plowing)
Soil-working tools other than the digging stick (e.g., hoe, spade, rake, footplow) or harvesting tools other than simple beating stick (e.g., flail, rice header, winnowing tray)
Animal-drawn plow
Fertilization of land with material other than wood ashes (including, e.g., animal manure, night soil, green manure, compost, fresh soil or mud)
Crop rotation

Trait_name: Increasing cultivable land by engineering methods
Trait_description: Area of cultivable land increased by engineering methods, including drainage, irrigation, and terracing

Trait_name: Reclamation of agricultural land by drainage
Trait_description: Reclamation of agricultural land by drainage
Irrigation
Permanent dams or dykes to impound water for irrigation, drinking, etc.
Terracing (including barriers to reduce soil slippage)
Continuous boundaries (other than growing food plants) delimit agricultural fields (e.g., fences, rows or walls of stone, paths, ditches, hedges)
Agricultural land reverts to chief, king or state as personal property or for reassignment when owner abandons the land or dies without heirs (i.e., escheat)
Agricultural lands reapportioned from time to time by the chief, tribe, or state to insure equitable distribution and/or maximum cultivation, rather than for services rendered
Agricultural land forfeited by a cultivator for failure to till it properly (i.e., state enforcement of maximum cultivation)
Political or religious officials or other specialists determine the time of carrying out various steps in the agricultural cycle

Trait_name: State or church provides farmers with equipment
Trait_description: State or church provides farmers with seed or tools
Surplus of food regularly produced over and above the annual subsistence needs of the food producers, and not consumed by them
State or tribal granaries on which two or more communities (or the army) might draw
Fruit or nut orchards planted
Domesticated animals kept (other than the dog)

Trait_name: Domesticated animals kept to provide food
Trait_description: Domesticated animals kept to provide food
Domesticated animals used for packing
Domesticated animals used for traction
Domesticated animals used for riding

Trait_name: Settlements occupied for more than 10 years
Trait_description: Settlements occupied for more than 10 years, on the average
Settlements permanent
Rectangular ground plan for settlements
Permanent communities (settled or nomadic) of about 100 or more members
Permanent communities (settled or nomadic) of about 500 or more members
Towns: permanent nucleated settlements of 2,000 or more residents
Two or more towns
City: administrative and commercial population center of at least 10,000 residents, most of whom are engaged in non-subsistence activities
Two or more cities
City of 100,000 or more residents

Trait_name: Cities divided into quarters or wards
Trait_description: Cities divided into quarters or wards
Planned cities
Paved streets
Paved plaza
Broad and well-maintained roads connecting settlements
Paved roads connecting settlements
Bridges (excluding log spans, vine ropes, and simple pole frameworks)
Permanently staffed way stations or inns along roads to house and provide for travelers
Civic or ceremonial structures (including men's house) not ordinarily used as dwellings by family units (excluding structures built for specific occasions and later abandoned or destroyed)
Grandstands, amphitheaters, or stadiums where spectators can witness contests or performances

Trait_name: Stone monuments commemorating persons or events
Trait_description: Stone monuments or stelae to mark or commemorate important persons or events
Aqueducts or conduits of stone or brick to supply drinking water
Cisterns: artificially lined rain-catching or water-holding basins
Baths of stone or brick
Drains: lined channels, covered or uncovered, or pipes, used to carry off rain water
Sewers: lined and covered channels or pipes, primarily for carrying away human waste
Permanent fortifications (including palisades around settlements, blockhouses, citadels, and fortified boundaries, but excluding fortified dwellings or compounds)
Walls of stone, brick, adobe, or beaten earth (including earthworks) used in fortification
Moats (excluding dry ditches) surrounding fortifications

Trait_name: Parts of houses extensively painted or carved
Trait_description: House walls, ceiling, or roof extensively painted or carved
Multi-roomed dwellings (three or more walled-off and separate rooms, with some degree of functional differentiation between them)
Multi-storied structures (not meant to include high storage platforms)
Cut stone masonry

Trait_name: Stone or brick bases for civic or ceremonial structures
Trait_description: Stone or brick substructures (e.g., platforms, truncated pyramids) used as bases for civic or ceremonial structures
Dwellings (including walls) constructed of cut stones

Trait_name: Civic or ceremonial buildings of cut stone
Trait_description: Civic or ceremonial buildings constructed of cut stone

Trait_name: Monumental architecture of stone or brick
Trait_description: Monumental architecture of stone or brick (e.g., pyramids, palaces, temples, fortresses, amphitheaters)
Quarrying of stone for construction (rather than merely dressing loose stones)
Stone coursing (blocks laid in successive horizontal layers)

Trait_name: Rubble used between walls in stone or brick construction
Trait_description: Rubble or some other fill used between walls in stone or brick construction
Fired brick used in construction
True mortar used in construction

Trait_name: Facing of stone or brick walls
Trait_description: Facing of stone or brick walls with plaster, alabaster, etc.

Trait_name: Roof of tile, brick, stone slabs, planks, etc.
Trait_description: Roofs of tile, brick, stone slabs, planks, etc. (i.e., not bark, mud, thatching, or similar material)
Stone lintels
Corbeled arch
True arch

Trait_name: Stone or brick pillars or columns used structurally
Trait_description: Stone or brick pillars or columns used structurally
Stone stairways (of cut blocks, or carved into living rock)
Architectural stone carving (beyond the cutting of stone into blocks)

Trait_name: Architectural features cut into living rock
Trait_description: Architectural features (e.g., tombs, stairways) cut into living rock

Trait_name: Fortresses built of stone or brick
Trait_description: Fortresses built of stone or brick (including walled cities and citadels, where people take refuge in time of war)
Elaborations in fortified walls (e.g., towers, salients, merlons)
Professional (full-time) architects or engineers
Professional (full-time) stone masons
Professional (full-time) carpenters or woodworkers
Landed property: continuous ownership rights exercised by individuals or families over land which has been improved, even after cultivated plot, house site, etc., is abandoned

Trait_name: Inscription of land or other forms of property
Trait_description: Inscription of land or other forms of property (registry of deeds)
Most individual (not family) property transmitted by inheritance rather than being destroyed at death of owner
Testamentary disposition of property, by a written will, through a formal executor, or orally in the presence of a witness

Marked differences in wealth (e.g., real property, livestock, precious metals, slaves) among members of the society (other than the difference between the principal political leader and everyone else)
Luxury items (other than symbols of political or religious office) which only a small percentage of the population (less than 20 percent) can afford
Craft specialization: some crafts which only a limited number of men in the society practice (excluding the making of religious or ceremonial objects by shamans or priests)
A significant amount of craft production primarily for economic exchange rather than for personal consumption
Full-time craft-specialists (e.g., brewer, lapidary, tailor, baker, tanner)
Full-time skilled service specialists (e.g., tattooer, barber, accountant, lawyer, physician)
Guilds of specialized artisans (i.e., cooperative associations)

Trait_name: State controls certain aspects of production
Trait_description: State controls certain aspects of production (e.g., licenses salt production, promotes raising of livestock, monopolizes weapons production, restricts private mining)

Trait_name: Institutional employment of artisans and laborers
Trait_description: Artisans and laborers attached to or employed on a regular basis (rather than under the corvée) by political or religious institutions (tribe or state, temple or church)
Corvée (draft labor exacted by a supra-community authority or agency)
Wage labor (unskilled laborers paid in money or in kind at prearranged rates and intervals)
Standardized medium of exchange, in terms of which the value of most commodities is reckoned
Coined money

Trait_name: Money or goods lent out at interest
Trait_description: Money or goods lent out at interest
Rental of land or dwellings by landlords to tenants as a common system of tenure
Itinerant merchants or traders who are members of the society itself (rather than foreigners), and who remain such even if they trade outside the society
Sedentary merchants who operate fixed commercial establishments
Markets, in which a variety of goods are traded
Daily and permanent markets
State regulation of commerce (e.g., taxes on economic transactions, fixing of price levels, enforcing payment of debts, supervising markets)
Economic transactions detailed in legally enforceable contracts
Long-term commercial records kept
Recorded inventories of wealth (e.g., with pebbles, knotted cords, notched sticks, clay tablets)
Royal storehouse or treasury (for hard goods, rather than for food) with accountant or treasurer who keeps track of the king's wealth
Trade between communities
Frequent or regular trade with other societies, involving journeys of at least 3 days one-way
State-directed trade (i.e., trade carried on by agents of the state with other societies)
Trading outposts maintained outside the territory of the society
Taxation in kind (including produce from land farmed for the state, but excluding required contributions to community projects or ceremonies)
Taxation in money
Official tax or tribute collectors sent out periodically by the central government
Tolls collected on roads or bridges
Serfs: propertyless class of agricultural laborers, bound to the land and producing for their masters
War captives or persons bought outside the society kept as slaves and usually not adopted, liberated, or killed subsequently (i.e. extrasocietal slavery)
Debtors or criminals made slaves, or other freeborn members of the society (including wives and children) sold into slavery (i.e., intrasocietal slavery)

Trait_name: Slaves bought and sold within the society
Trait_description: Slaves bought and sold within the society (excluding the selling into slavery of freeborn members of the society)

Social segments above the level of the extended family or household (e.g., lineages, sibs, moieties, marriage classes, castes, age grades, men's clubs, secret societies, warrior societies, ceremonial teams, craft guilds)
Unilineal kin groups beyond extended families (including royal lineages)
Well-defined and significant differences in social status (other than the difference between the principal political leader and everyone else)

Trait_name: Social stratification into at least three classes
Trait_description: Stratification of society into at least three distinct social classes (e.g., kings, nobles, commoners, slaves)

Trait_name: Two or more ranked groups of upper classes
Trait_description: Upper classes differentiated into two or more ranked groups

Trait_name: Ornaments or clothing distinguishing social classes
Trait_description: Special ornaments or differences in clothing which distinguish members of the upper classes from the rest of the society
Sumptuary laws concerning dress, adornment, or other manifestations of wealth and serving to maintain class distinctions

Trait_name: Upper class members have superior residences
Trait_description: Members of upper classes (other than ruler) have distinctly superior residences

Trait_name: Upper class members have more land
Trait_description: Members of upper classes (other than ruler) have significantly more land or property than commoners

Trait_name: Upper class members are extempt from taxation
Trait_description: Members of upper classes (outside of the royal family) are extempt from taxation

Trait_name: Upper class members have servants or retainers
Trait_description: Members of upper classes (other than ruler) have permanent servants or retainers

Trait_name: Upper class members have numerous wives or concubines
Trait_description: Members of upper classes usually have numerous wives or concubines (at least 4 or 5)

Trait_name: Competitive sports or spectacles held for the upper classes
Trait_description: Competitive sports or spectacles held primarily for the entertainment of the upper classes

Trait_name: Dramatic performances for upper class entertainment
Trait_description: Dramatic performances held primarily for the entertainment of the upper classes

Trait_name: Professional dancers or musicians for upper classes
Trait_description: Professional dancers or musicians who provide entertainment during feasts, banquets, or celebrations of the upper classes

Trait_name: Class differences in disposal of the dead
Trait_description: Status or class differences in disposal of the dead (based on social rather than religious status; exclude shamans and priests)

Trait_name: Upper class members buried with luxury goods
Trait_description: Members of upper classes (other than ruler) buried with luxury goods

Trait_name: Upper class members buried with wives, retainers or slaves
Trait_description: Members of upper classes (other than ruler) buried with wives, concubines, retainers, or slaves
Members of upper classes (other than ruler) buried in elaborate tombs or graves (e.g., burial mounds, cist graves, thatched buildings)
Communities (or camps) continuously grouped (year-round) into larger political units
Districts or provinces, each comprising several villages or communities, are permanently grouped into a larger political unit

State: permanent organization of a number of supra-community units (districts, tribes, or provinces) into a single political unit under centralized control, involving at least (a) some power to collect revenue, (b) some centralized judicial authority, and (c) the power to formulate and execute policy
Empire: a unit of two or more formerly independent states covering a considerable area
Decisions or policy made by a formally recognized agent or agency of the society (e.g., headman, chief, king, or council in which membership is not based merely on age or sex)
Political leader(s) has considerable authority, by virtue of his office rather than his personality
Regular advisor(s) or assistant(s) to the principal political leader (e.g., sub-chief, talking chief, minister, council)

Trait_name: Political leader is a full-time specialist
Trait_description: Political leader is a full-time specialist (i.e., does not regularly engage in subsistence)

Monarchy: a government in which the king is the ultimate source of authority and exercises such powers as the following: the power to conscript an army or a labor force, strong executive power, the power to declare war, the power of life and death, etc.
State or tribe has capital city or town
Provincial or district administrative centers where officials appointed by the state (other than local chiefs) collect taxes or maintain order
Governors or chiefs, appointed or confirmed in office, in charge of administering districts or provinces

Trait_name: Three or more levels of territorial administration
Trait_description: Three or more levels of territorial administration above the community (e.g., 1. district, 2. province, 3. quarter, 4. kingdom)
Officials in charge of municipal administration (e.g., mayors, bailiffs)
Hierarchy of non-territorial administrative officials (exclude palace hierarchy)
State ministers in charge of various activities controlled or supervised by the state (e.g., minister of agriculture, minister of public works, minister of war, minister of foreign affairs)

Trait_name: Council of ministers advising the ruler
Trait_description: Council of ministers forming a regular advisory body to the ruler
Prime minister: principal administrative officer below the ruler and appointed by him

Trait_name: Three or more levels of administrative officials
Trait_description: Hierarchy of at least three levels of administrative officials (including the paramount chief or king)
Inspectors, censors, or secret agents who investigate the functioning of officials, popular discontent, etc.
Professional civil service: administrative positions filled on the basis of merit and training, rather than on the basis of kinship ties, wealth, social status, or personal allegiance to the ruler
State-sponsored colonists
Succession to political leadership by a clear and regularly followed procedure (e.g., primogeniture, formal election)
Political leader appoints and deposes political officials

Trait_name: Political leader bestows land, slaves, rank
Trait_description: Political leader bestows land, slaves, or noble rank for services rendered
Ruler grants audiences to hear grievances or petitions
Political leader exercises considerable control over religious institutions (e.g., performs investiture of priests, endows temples)
Political leader has full-time personal attendants and retainers

Trait_name: Ruler has many wives or concubines
Trait_description: Chief or king has many wives or concubines (at least 8 or 10)
Chief or king has a harem (a special residence(s) supervised by a responsible official(s), e.g., a eunuch)
Body guard to protect the ruler's person
Court, characterized by a household staff and steward, resident members of the upper classes, state or tribal officials, entertainers, etc.
Political leader lives in a special residence or compound significantly larger and more elaborate than any other residence
Royal estates, residences, or preserves outside the capital which are the property of the king
Special ceremony for installation or investiture of new political leader (e.g., oath of office, coronation)

Trait_name: Ruler has special symbols of office
Trait_description: Chief or king has special symbols of office or authority (e.g., throne, crown, scepter, seal)
Devices used to confirm and authenticate state orders, decrees, actions, and transactions (e.g., seals, signatures, rings, or other graphic evidence)
Displays of special deference to political leader (e.g., carrying in a litter, averting the eyes, bowing)

Trait_name: Officials or sub-chiefs swear allegiance to the leader
Trait_description: Officials, sub-chiefs, or courtiers swear allegiance to the king or state

Trait_name: Political leader performs essential societal rituals
Trait_description: Political leader performs rituals considered essential for the welfare of the society, and which only he can perform
Ruler considered divine or semi-divine
Paramount chief or king buried with luxury goods
Ruler buried in an elaborate tomb or grave (e.g., burial mound, cist grave, thatched building, pyramid)

Trait_name: Ruler buried with wives or slaves
Trait_description: Wives, concubines, retainers, or slaves of chief or king buried with him at the time of his death

Trait_name: Special preservation of the ruler's corpse
Trait_description: Special preservation (e.g., desiccation, embalming) of the ruler's corpse or part thereof
Deceased former political leader especially reverenced (e.g., his spirit invoked or propitiated, monuments erected to his memory)
Superordinate tribe or state which receives tribute, labor, soldiers, or other recognition of obligation from subordinate or vassal tribe(s) or state(s)
Formal treaties (recorded or witnessed and sworn) concluded to establish alliances, to settle disputes, or to end wars
Ambassador(s): diplomatic representatives acting in regular relations with a foreign government

Trait_name: Young persons sent to capital for training or royal service
Trait_description: Young persons sent to capital from each district for training or royal service

Trait_name: State schools for upper class members
Trait_description: State schools for secular training of members of the upper classes

Trait_name: Crimes punished by a permanent agent
Trait_description: Crimes regularly punished by a permanent agent of the society rather than by the offended parties themselves

Peace-making machinery or institution for settling disputes and avoiding fighting within the community (either a permanent mediator, e.g., chief or council, whose neutrality and wisdom are generally accepted, or an arbitrator, e.g., the state, backed by sanctions of force)

Trait_name: Inter-community disputes settled by peaceful means
Trait_description: Inter-community disputes within the tribe or state customarily settled by peaceful means (e.g., arbitration, official decrees) rather than by fighting

Judicial process, in which an individual or limited group (e.g., council of elders, tribal chief, court of law) considers evidence and renders judgment in a dispute, or of an accused person, on behalf of the society
Court trials, held under judges or magistrates who hear testimony and weigh evidence, interpret the law, and render a decision in civil or criminal cases

Trait_name: Judicial system of higher and lower courts
Trait_description: Judicial system of higher and lower courts, cases being referred to one or the other according to their nature, with decisions of lower courts perhaps appealable to higher courts
Political leader exercises judicial power (decides guilt and decrees punishment, or settles cases appealed to him)
Ruler sometimes pardons convicted offenders
Ruler functions as lawgiver or lawmaker
Code of laws (explicit and recorded) which covers broad areas of social, political, and economic relations

Trait_name: Class distinctions in legal liability for offenses
Trait_description: Class distinctions in legal liability for offenses (i.e., members of the various social classes have different rights under the law)
Graded series of punishments or fines specified by a central agency of the society (e.g., tribal council, ruler, legislature) and consistently applied to fit a graded series of offenses
Certain offenses punished by fines (in money or in kind) paid to tribe or state, of which part may go to the offended party

Trait_name: Offenses punished by confiscation of property
Trait_description: Certain offenses punished by confiscation of property, of which part may go to the offended party
Corporal punishment (including mutilation) meted out for certain offenses by an authorized agent of the society

Trait_name: Offenses punished by slavery or hard labor
Trait_description: Certain offenses punished by slavery or by terms at hard labor
Death penalty decreed for certain crimes and exacted openly by a constituted agent of the society

Trait_name: Violation of secular law incurs divine and secular punishment
Trait_description: Violation of secular legal norms automatically incurs punishment by gods as well as secular punishment
Police force: permanent agency of the state charged with apprehension and detention of criminals
Incarceration of convicted offenders (in stocks, pens, cages, or prisons)

Warfare motivated primarily by economic considerations (e.g., territorial acquisition, the capture of booty, the taking of slaves) rather than by feuds, the avenging of murder or witchcraft, or the taking of women
Recognized war leader(s) (distinct from the political leader) who regularly lead(s) the men of the society against the enemy (e.g., war chief, general)
Professional military commanders (e.g., generals) who regularly lead the army in time of war
Professional middle-level military officials (e.g., centurions, lieutenants, captains)
Body of specially trained or highly skilled warriors
Military conscription
Soldiers take oath of allegiance
Standing army, organized around a core of professional soldiers
Mercenaries (i.e., paid foreign troops) used in warfare
Espionage, by special agents who pass for natives in enemy territory
Defensive body armor (excluding shields)
Pitched battles: encounters frequently fought hand-to-hand rather than hit-and-run
Military formations and tactics used in warfare (including the holding of men in reserve, but excluding ambushes and hit-and-run raids)
Emblems, banners, or special objects which serve to identify military units and act as rallying points are carried into battle
Differentiated military units (e.g., spearmen, bowmen, slingers, cavalry)
Chariots used in warfare
Permanently garrisoned forts (excluding observation posts, walled towns and cities)
Sieges laid to enemy fortifications strong enough to resist immediate assault

Trait_name: Catapult-type devices used as siege engines
Trait_description: Catapult-type devices used as siege engines

Trait_name: Special ornaments for brave or wounded warriors
Trait_description: Special ornaments, insignia, or appellations awarded for prowess or wounds received in battle
Outstanding warriors rewarded with gifts of property, women, or slaves
Nobility or distinctly high social status attainable through war exploits
Body trophies (e.g., heads, scalps, hands) taken in war or from sacrificed prisoners
Adult male war captives frequently taken

Trait_name: War captives regularly sacrificed to gods
Trait_description: War captives regularly sacrificed to god(s)
Ransoming of war captives
Territory of vanquished enemy annexed
Peoples of vanquished enemy subjugated and held under effective control

Trait_name: Defeated political leaders pledge loyalty to conquerors
Trait_description: Defeated political leader(s) or his heir retained in authority over his territory on pledge of loyalty to conquerors
Periodic revolts of subject peoples
God(s) of war (not necessarily connected exclusively with war)

God(s): supernatural beings (not impersonal forces) who are not particular to locations or to kinship segments (exclude, e.g., ancestral, guardian, and other personal spirits), to whom prayers are directed and who actively intervene in human affairs

Patron gods (not including guardian spirits), who afford protection to individuals engaged in particular occupations or activities (e.g., god of merchants, god of hunters, god of travelers, god of blacksmiths)
Oracle(s): a shrine or object where, or by means of which, a priest or priestess transmits answers to questions posed to a god or spirit
Lawgiver god, who on more than one occasion has enunciated extensive rules for governing human conduct
Sun god worshipped (i.e., propitiated and invoked)

Pantheon of gods worshipped (propitiated and invoked): applies only to differentiated gods who actively control spheres of life or nature, e.g., rain god, war god, fire god, fertility goddess, love goddess
One god in the pantheon of differentiated gods worshipped as paramount
Idols worshipped as representations of supernatural beings
Offerings, libations, or sacrifices to supernatural beings (gods, ancestors, local spirits)
Human sacrifice directed to supernatural beings to placate them or gain their favor
Altars, where offerings (including sacrifices) or prayers to gods are regularly made or rituals performed
Special religious practitioners (e.g., shamans, priests)

Trait_name: Religious specialists supported by individuals or society
Trait_description: Religious specialist(s) supported (fully or almost fully) by individuals, the community, tribe, or state
Priests: religious practitioners connected with specific gods or with society-wide ancestral cults; i.e., not shamans

Trait_name: Priests formally invested in their office
Trait_description: Priests formally invested in their office by chief, king, or higher priests
Functionally specialized priests (e.g., interpreters of oracles or dreams, sacrificial priests, funerary priests)
Hierarchy of priests
Temples, where gods are worshipped or society-wide ancestral cults are practiced by priests
Temple has large staff (more than 10 )
Temple owns considerable property

Trait_name: Women consecrated to a temple or a god service
Trait_description: Women consecrated to a temple or to the service of a god (e.g., priestesses, virgins, nuns)
Church: religious institution which encompasses a number of priests and temples (or monks and monasteries) and which is unified by a set of common beliefs and observances

Trait_name: Head priest has considerable political influence
Trait_description: Head priest (including priest-chief or priest-king) has considerable political influence

Trait_name: Church owns large amounts of land
Trait_description: Church owns large amounts of land
Temple or church receives donations
Temple or church exacts tithes or receives the produce of a proportion of all cultivated lands
Training school for priests

Trait_name: Priests follow strict rules of discipline
Trait_description: Priests follow strict rules of discipline, including various forms of abegnation (e.g., fasting, continence) or mortification of the flesh
Monasteries, convents, or nunneries where priests, priestesses, etc., live, and which, unlike temples, are ordinarily closed to laymen
Ceremonial or religious center: a complex of temples and associated buildings having an important role in the religious life of the society
Religious pilgrimages to shrines or sacred places
Ritual or liturgical (written) texts
Pottery (either made or used commonly)
Painted pottery made
Effigy vessels made
Mold-made pottery
Wheel-made pottery
Pottery kilns
Men make the pottery
Professional (full-time) potters
Professional (full-time) painters or sculptors
Terracotta (baked clay) figurines or statues as art or ceremonial objects
Stone statues (or figurines) as art or ceremonial objects
Heroic or gigantic stone statues
Reliefs, intaglios, or friezes carved into dressed stone surfaces
Murals or frescoes painted on faced stone or brick walls
Glass manufactured

Trait_name: Mosaics of stone, brick, tile, or glass
Trait_description: Mosaics of stone, brick, tile, or glass

Trait_name: Ground or polished stone cutting tools
Trait_description: Ground or polished stone cutting tools
Metal axes or adzes made
Animal-powered devices for grinding grain
Mechanical devices for raising water (e.g., shadoof, water wheel)
Wheeled vehicles
Scales or balances
Spindle
Heddle loom
Hair, wool, fur, or silk woven into cloth
Patterns woven into cloth
Garments made of woven cloth
Dyeing of finished, loom-woven textiles
Professional weavers, who weave cloth primarily for exchange
Forging (hammering metal into shape while hot)
Mining of ores
Smelting of ores
Bellows used in working metal
Copper mined and worked

Trait_name: Gold and/or silver mined and worked
Trait_description: Gold and/or silver mined and worked
Iron mined and worked
Alloying of metals
Bronze or brass produced
Casting in molds
Lost-wax casting (cire perdue)

Trait_name: Metal hardening through annealing or tempering
Trait_description: Altering the hardness of metals by annealing (heating and slow cooling) or tempering (heating and rapid cooling by immersion in a liquid)

Trait_name: Soldering, welding, or riveting used to join metals
Trait_description: Soldering, welding, or riveting used to join metals
Decorative metal-working techniques (e.g., gilding, embossing, engraving, inlaying)
Copper weapons or utensils in common use
Bronze or brass weapons or utensils in common use
Iron weapons or utensils in common use
Metal weapons and utensils predominant

Trait_name: Ornaments and jewelry of precious metals
Trait_description: Ornaments and jewelry of gold, silver, or other precious metals
Non-utilitarian objects made of metal (e.g., figurines or statues, ceremonial chalices, solar discs)

Trait_name: Precious or semiprecious stones used for jewelry
Trait_description: Precious or semi-precious stones used for jewelry
Professional smiths, who work metal primarily for exchange
Watercraft (excluding floating logs and simple rafts)
Boats built from several planks (excluding strakes)
Vessels propelled by oars
Vessels propelled by sails
Cabins on board vessels
Navy: fleet of specially designed warships maintained by the state
Professional boatbuilders (including part-time specialists)
Professional sailors, pilots, or navigators (including part-time specialists)

Trait_name: Voyages undertaken out of sight of land
Trait_description: Voyages undertaken out of sight of land
Water boiled in a container over a fire, rather than by hot stones dropped into it
Standardized weights and measures (excluding measurement with parts of the body, and similarly variable measurements)
System of numbers extending beyond 100
Mathematics (beyond simple addition and subtraction)

Trait_name: Mnemonic devices for recording traditions, events, etc.
Trait_description: Traditions, events, etc., recorded by means of mnemonic devices (excluding simple records of elapsed time or simple inventories)
System of writing (including extensive systems of standardized pictographs)
Fully phonetic system of writing
Scribes (other than priests)
Teachers: professional, secular instructors
Techniques of surveying and mensuration (including, e.g., plumb lines, knowledge of right angle, stretched cords, but excluding swinging of circles by means of a cord)
Astronomical observations regularly made by priests or other specialists
Calendrical system, uniquely designating each day of the year, based on solar or stellar observations
Census taken
Surgery practiced (excluding, e.g., the setting of broken bones, removal of arrows, bloodletting)
